data.title: What it Means to Dream in a Second Language
data.meta_description: What if feels like to dream in French and Italian, and tips on how to dream in another language. The link between fluency and dreaming in a language.
data.text:
There’s a common idea that you know you’re fluent in a language if you dream in it.

But as a native English speaker who has studied French and Italian, I don’t think the theory is correct. While dreaming in a foreign language does indicate some degree of proficiency at the very least, you don’t have to be fluent in it to dream in it.

Let me explain.

My first French dream

The first time I “heard” French in a dream was in 2008. I was on a high school exchange in the South of France and was speaking French every day. While my French was far from fluent upon arrival in the country, after a few weeks I began to feel more and more confident in the language.

This culminated in a moment, early one morning, when I found myself in earshot, as it were, of a conversation in a dream that went something like this:

Hypothetical dream character 1 : Tu aimes le chocolat ?

Hypothetical dream character 2 : Oui, je l’aime bien !

Do you like chocolate? Yes, I like it a lot!

As you can tell, the conversation was far from sophisticated. But the mere novelty of…
